did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle:
Roxane Connick Carlisle collection
1963-1984
did.physdesc: 190 sound tapes (reels, cassettes) : analog ; various sizes
278 photographic prints : black-and white, color ; various sizes

descriptivenote.p: In English, Arabic, and sung in other languages.

corpname.part: American Folklife Center, Library of Congress

did.abstract:
Collection of field recordings, photographs, video recordings, a film, and manuscripts created by Roxane Connick Carlisle primarily in Darfur Province and other locations in the Sudan region, which now includes South Sudan, from 1963-1968. The collection also includes photographs of musicians, musical instruments, markets, gardens, buildings, weddings, and wildlife taken in Sudan, Somalia, Kenya, and Uganda from 1963-1968. Includes field recordings of music of various groups and photographs of musicians including Anuak, Baggara, Beni Halba, Bederiya, Dinka, Fur, Nuer, Ingessana, Shilluk, Ta'isha, Zaghawa, and other people, documenting wedding music, women's song and poetry traditions, and other music and ceremonies. The collection includes eight audio tape reels of oud music, songs, and interviews with noted Sudanese musician Abdel Karim el Kably recorded in 1963. The collection also includes recordings of the radio series,
Listen to the World
from 1971-1973, broadcast on CHEX-FM, Peterborough, Ontario. The shows were produced, written, and narrated by Roxane Connick Carlisle. Sound recordings for radio programs, demonstration, and teaching ethnomusicology include music from Afghanistan, other locations in Africa (Ethiopia, Burundi, and more), Australia and Papua New Guinea, Brazil, Bulgaria, China, India, Indonesia, Japan, North American Indian, Philippines, Polynesia, Southeast Asia, and Spain, and include recordings for Alan Lomax's Cantometrics project. The collection includes recordings of several speeches and interviews by Roxane Carlisle, including her interview with Ahmed Diraige, governor of Darfur, March 1983.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The collection was processed by Marcia K. Segal.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Sudanese music performed by Abdel Karim Al-Kabli (AFC 2015/045), American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C. This collection contains materials documenting a concert held in the Whittall Pavilion co-sponsored by the Library of Congress and the American Folklife Center featuring Abdel Karim Al-Kabli.
Audiovisual Archives at the Canadian Museum of History (formerly the Canadian Museum of Civilization). The Archives keeps a set of Carlisle's field recordings.
University of Khartoum. Sudan Research Unit. The University keeps a set of Carlisle's field recordings.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Duplication of collection materials may be governed by copyright and other restrictions.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p:
The Roxanne Connick Carlisle collection is open for research. To request materials, please contact the Folklife Reading Room at
https://hdl.loc.gov/loc.afc/folklife.contact
Certain restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: [item, date, container number], Roxanne Connick Carlisle collection (AFC 2012/008), American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p:
Roxane Connick Carlisle has served as President of the Institute for Development of Education through the Arts (1987-1990), worked as Special Advisor to the President on the Integration of Women in Development, Canadian International Development Agency (CIDA; 1976-1983), and taught anthropology at Trent University, Peterborough, Ontario, Canada (1970-1972), in addition to other roles in sponsored travel and research (including a Fulbright Fellowship, 1962-1963). She did fieldwork in 1963 and 1967 in various areas of the Sudan, before South Sudan gained its independence, and documented various aspects of cultural traditions for several tribes. She has worked for the Canadian International Development Agency, in part to provide research and guidance towards programs that improve the welfare of women in developing countries. As an ethnomusicologist and educator, she has published works that support the inclusion of world music in universities. Her radio program,
Listen to the World
was an early introduction to world music for a general audience. Carlisle's career has been, in its many aspects, a means by which traditions on the verge of change are documented, maintained (in memory if not in practice), and shared with various audiences.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p:
Collection of field recordings, photographs, video recordings, a film, and manuscripts created by Roxane Connick Carlisle primarily in Darfur Province and other locations in the Sudan region, which now includes South Sudan, from 1963-1968. The collection also includes photographs of musicians, musical instruments, markets, gardens, buildings, weddings, and wildlife taken in Sudan, Somalia, Kenya, and Uganda from 1963-1968. Includes field recordings of music of various groups and photographs of musicians including Anuak, Baggara, Beni Halba, Bederiya, Dinka, Fur, Nuer, Ingessana, Shilluk, Ta'isha, Zaghawa, and other people, documenting wedding music, women's song and poetry traditions, and other music and ceremonies. The collection includes eight audio tape reels of oud music, songs, and interviews with noted Sudanese musician Abdel Karim el Kably recorded in 1963. The collection also includes recordings of the radio series,
Listen to the World
from 1971-1973, broadcast on CHEX-FM, Peterborough, Ontario. The shows were produced, written, and narrated by Roxane Connick Carlisle. Sound recordings for radio programs, demonstration, and teaching ethnomusicology include music from Afghanistan, other locations in Africa (Ethiopia, Burundi, and more), Australia and Papua New Guinea, Brazil, Bulgaria, China, India, Indonesia, Japan, North American Indian, Philippines, Polynesia, Southeast Asia, and Spain, and include recordings for Alan Lomax's Cantometrics project. The collection includes recordings of several speeches and interviews by Roxane Carlisle, including her interview with Ahmed Diraige, governor of Darfur, March 1983.

did.unittitle: Subseries 2: Lectures, presentations and interviews

Roxane Carlisle's lecture in Khartoum,
April 1967

scopecontent.p: Tape of illustrations for the lecture. Ethnomusicology in fieldwork given with musical examples from two Nuer, two Nuba Mountains, Kordofan; two Shilluk of Arkuwa; three Dinka; three Pari Lokoro of Lafon Hill. Audience: British High Commissioner, American Embassy, Sudanese ministries.

did.unittitle:
Interview with Roxane McCollester and Dr. Yousif Fadl Hassan (
Voice of America
),
April 8, 1967

scopecontent.p: Includes music excerpts: Haddendoa (rebab), el Kably (ud and song), Anuak (men's chorus), Dinka (Lual B [?] camp solo), Nuba of Salara (flute solo), Beni Halba (nahass drumming patterns), Rizeigat (women and men dancing), Fur of Girri (orchestra). This copy recorded at 3 3/4 ips from the original, recorded at 7 1/2 ips.

el Kably interview, three songs,
September 5, 1963

Sudan: the music and songs of Abdel Karim el Kably,
August 1963

scopecontent.p:
See box-folder
1/12
. 3 pages of handwritten notes by Abdel Karim el Kably accompanied SR191. This broad overview about music in Sudan was written for Carlisle at el Kably's home in Khartoum North in August 1963.

did.unittitle: Series 3: Photographs
did.physdesc: Due to the small space in which to write on the slide mats, some of the information is unclear or difficult to understand. Carlisle's spelling of proper names of locations or ethnic groups reflect contemporary spelling. In these cases, the first instance is revised to reflect current usage, and all instances after that silently revised.
